PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it will exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if necessary or don't hesitate to give details or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been completed or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer:

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Folklore in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preparation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: Bernhard A. Friesen
2. Your address: 547
3. Date: July 26, 1955
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Saskatchewan
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and Year): May 1893
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
   - Guelph, Manitoba (typed three months)
   - Ontario (typed three months)

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", etc.)
   - 12 years

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   - Because the Canadian government had an agreement to provide land at low prices to homesteaders to help settle family and make a living over.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroads or government information?)
    - Through government information.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

   Because the Canadian government had then opened up the land for settlement and the country offered free homesteads to families who wanted to own their own land.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

    Through government information.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They came along. Some were disappointed in Saskatchewan but here building as being very cold.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? Traveled with family.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Train and steamship were used all the way.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.). An Indian woman carried a papoose on her back.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? Lived in a boxcar at the stopping place until school was started on homestead.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? NE¼ Sec. 12 Tp. 19 R4 W½ Mer. new homestead.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. Living near Redden all the time.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came? Farming before and after coming to Western Canada.

An Okotoks woman carried a horse on her back.

Bird in a boxcar at the stopping place until dark were excited on homesteads.

During new frontier all the time.

Planning life and after coming to Western Canada.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

Travelling with family.

Bird in a boxcar at the stopping place until dark were located on land.

NE¼ Sec. 17 To 13 R4 W3 Mer. New Frontier.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Living new Frontier all the time.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

*Rothlen, similar.*

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

*Yes. The Carlton Hotel line the N.R. built about 1909, thereby taking a lot of trade away from Rothlen, giving it to Carlton. And still further.*

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

*Every two-three weeks. Tuesday and Saturday.*

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

*Right from the start due to Saturday hunting.*

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?

*What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what proportion of your total purchases were by mail order and changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.*

*About 1908. A hunting camp. A very small percentage of total purchase was made by mail order and now it is practically nil.*

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

*1912. Rothlen Rural Telephone Co.*

*When coming to Saskatchewan the first time the idea wasn't to try it out and then decide. The decision to stay was made after the homestead was declared and receiving the naturalization papers in 1996.*

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes, re-employment.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return? No.

We do not live we only stay.

We are too poor to get away.

36. If you or some members of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Secretary treasurer of Bicknell School district #52 from 1905 to 1916. Volunteer of the school church for 12 years.

Almost 1920-1932. Also worked for local telephone company for many years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were first to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible.

Such as owning the first automobile, combining organizing the first lodge, etc...

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin of naming of the place; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any changes in name since the first name was given; date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

School district #52 named after "place" suggested by farmer Henry Demmler in Russia.

Post office was named before our arrival and no one seems to know origin and meaning of name.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

We do not have any record of people moving away.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

We do not have any record of people moving away.

36. If you or some members of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, mention its name, giving dates wherever possible.

Secretary, Friesen School District #252, 1905-1916. President of the school board for about 1920-1932. Also director for rural telephone company for many years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were elected to have or do something in the district, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

(Such as owning the first automobile, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, etc.) Give the name and date of its adoption. Try to give the origin of the name. (1) Name of place, (2) Date of adoption, (3) Origin of name.

School district #252 named "Friesenfield" after the pioneer who farmed there. Post office was named after our arrival and no one seems to know origin and meaning of name.
